Scheme 2 A highly accessible and robust carbon-coated cobalt nanoparticle catalyst for furfural hydrogenative valorization at mild reaction Wu Liu Investigation Validation Data curation a Jieying Hua Investigation Methodology a Shuyi Su Formal analysis a Xu Yang Conceptualization Methodology Writing – original draft Formal analysis Resources a b ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, 510006, China School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry Guangdong University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 China aSchool of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, 510006, China b Jieyang Branch of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Guangdong Laboratory (Rongjiang Laboratory), Jieyang 515200, China Jieyang Branch of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Guangdong Laboratory (Rongjiang Laboratory) Jieyang 515200 China bJieyang Branch of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Guangdong Laboratory (Rongjiang Laboratory), Jieyang 515200, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The hydrogenative upgrading of furfural into valuable chemical intermediates has currently caught intensive research interest, with robust and efficient catalysts that can operate under mild reaction conditions remaining challenging. In this study, we presented a high-performance carbon-coated cobalt catalyst (Co@C) through pyrolysis of sheet-like Co-MOF. The optimized Co@C-T550 exhibited an intriguing furfural conversion rate under a very mild reaction condition of 80 °C and 1 MPa. The catalyst's enhanced activity at low-temperature effectively suppressed side reactions, resulting in an excellent furfuryl alcohol productivity of 4.8 gFOL·gCo −1·h−1, surpassing most cobalt-based catalysts reported in recent literature. Furthermore, the high performance of Co@C-T550 can be sustained with slight decay even after undergoing 10 recycling runs, underscoring the reliable stability of the catalyst. Structure characterizations have revealed that this novel Co@C-T550 had highly dispersed cobalt nanoparticles with a microporous carbon coating, affording a high number of metallic cobalt sites with an excellent ability to resist cobalt sintering/leaching and re-oxidation. The insights gained from this study provide a solid foundation for the rational design of advanced carbon-coated cobalt catalysts for low-temperature hydrogenative biomass upgrading. Introduction Production of chemical intermediates from renewable biomass has currently attracted unprecedented attention; it can significantly mitigate carbon emissions caused by human activities owing to the establishment of a closed loop of carbon footprint between human society and nature [1–3]. In biomass refining, the hydrogenation process plays a pivotal role due to the abundant oxygen content present in these biomass-derived platform molecules. However, the utilization of high-efficacy metal catalysts in hydrogenation is recognized as one of the key bottlenecks impeding its further development [4–8]. Cobalt is a widely used metal catalyst in hydrogenation due to its efficient ability to dissociate hydrogen molecules. The Co0 species are the active centers responsible for catalytic activity, and therefore, the cobalt catalyst necessitates an activation process to retain a high content of metallic state [9,10]. This activation is typically achieved by in situ hydrogen-reduction at 400–600 °C in the fix-bed reactor[11,12]. Nevertheless, this method is not readily available for use in batch reactors where a large part of biomass refineries proceed [13,14]. Consequently, surface re-oxidation of cobalt is inevitable, leading to a decrease in the number of active sites on the catalyst surface [15]. As such, the existing cobalt catalysts often require high reaction temperatures (>150 °C) to attain a comparable conversion rate. Thereby, two unfavorable issues arise from the high-temperature reaction: one is the loss of active sites by metal sintering/leaching [16,17], and the other is the declined selectivity caused by the side reactions (hydrodeoxygenation, ring hydrogenation, etc.)[18]. To overcome these drawbacks, numerous methods have been reported in designing cobalt catalysts with a high number of active sites, such as alloying second metal [19–21], adding a promoter [22], constructing single atom catalyst [23], encapsulating a protective shell [24,25], etc. In particular, encapsulating the cobalt nanoparticles with a porous carbon shell has emerged as a viable and appealing strategy. The presence of a carbon coating provides numerous advantages, including effective isolation of highly dispersed cobalt nanoparticles, substantial resistance to particle aggregation, metal leaching and surface re-oxidation. The carbon shell can be sourced from diverse carbon-containing molecules or compounds [10,21]. For instance, Wang et al. presented a modified approach by utilizing fumaric and glycerol as co-templates to synthesize a novel Co@CN-G-600 catalyst, achieving an exceptional performance toward furfural hydrogenation at 80 °C and 2 MPa [26]. Furthermore, various representative Co-containing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), such as ZIF-67, ZIF-8 UIO-66, ZIF-67, etc., have also been employed to in situ generate carbon-coated cobalt catalysts [27,28,29,30]. Moon's group recently reported that a ZIF-67 derived Co/NC-400–6 achieved a remarkable productivity of 2-methyl furan at 180 °C [15]. Upon carefully reviewing the literature, we found that the catalytic performance of the as-obtained Co@C composites strongly relies on the kind of carbon template selected and the pyrolysis process (temperature, time, atmosphere, etc.); realizing an excellent performance under mild reaction temperatures (<100 °C) remains a challenging target[31–33]. A detailed summary of the reported catalytic performances is provided in Table S1 of the Supporting Information (SI). Encouraged by the above consideration, herein we have chosen to adopt sheet-like Co-MOF, where the terephthalic acid (H2-BDC) is used as an organic ligand, as the template for synthesizing a carbon-coated cobalt catalyst for liquid-phase furfural hydrogenation. To the best of our knowledge, using this Co-MOF-derived Co@C for furfural hydrogenation has been rarely reported[34,35]. By optimizing the pyrolysis process, we acquired a core-shell structured Co@C composited catalyst with a uniform particle size of 15∼20 nm and good oxidation-resist properties. The resulting Co@C can accomplish an outstanding yield of furfuryl alcohol at a very mild reaction of 80 °C and 1 MPa. Systematic structure characterizations and controlled experimental runs were performed to elucidate the relationship between the pyrolysis temperature, the structural properties (porosity, cobalt phase, morphology, etc.), and the activity. Experiment Catalyst preparation All the agents were used as received. Synthesis of Co-MOF: Co-MOF was synthesized using a simple solvothermal method with slight modification[34,36], as shown in Scheme 1 . First of all, 21 mL of deionized water (DI water), ethanol and dimethylformamide (DMF) were mixed and kept stirring. Then, 0.25 g cobalt acetate hydrate (C4H6CoO4·4H2O), and 0.17 g 2,5-Dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H2-BDC) was added into the above mixed solution. After stirring for 30 min, the mixed solution was transferred to a 100 mL polytetrafluoroethylene autoclave and heated to 120 °C for 12 h. After the reaction was completed and cooled to room temperature, the sample was obtained by centrifugation, washing and drying. Preparation of carbon-coated cobalt composited catalyst, Co@C: The as-prepared Co-MOF was annealed at 550 °C for 2 h in Ar with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 to obtain the carbon-coated cobalt composited catalyst. To investigate the effect of pyrolysis temperature on the resulting structural properties, we prepared a series of samples by the same procedure but varying the pyrolysis temperature from 300 to 600 °C; this series of samples were denoted as Co@C-T-n, where the T-n refers to the pyrolysis temperatures. Structure characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained with a D/Max-IIIA X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) using Cu Kα radiation. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out with a STA409PC thermogravimetric analyzer (Netzsch, German). The temperature range was 30 to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a nitrogen or air atmosphere (25 mL/min). Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR) was conducted on a Tensor 27 spectrometer (Bruker, USA) in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1 to obtain the IR spectra of the sample. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was done using a Sigma 300 FESEM (ZEISS, German) to observe morphological and structural analysis. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out on a JEM-2010 microscope (JEOL, Japan) using an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured with a Tristar 3010 isothermal nitrogen sorption analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) using a continuous adsorption procedure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with an AXIS Ultra DLD (Kratos, Britain) to examine the electronic properties of catalysts. Catalyst evaluation Selective hydrogenation of furfural (FUR) was performed to evaluate the catalyst performance. In a typical experiment, 3 mmol furfural and 30 mg catalyst were dispersed in 10 mL ethanol. The mixture was transferred into a 25 ml autoclave (CF-0.05, HONGYI Instrument) equipped with a pressure gage. The autoclave was sealed, purged with H2 five times, and then filled with pressurized H2 to the required pressure. The autoclave was heated to the required temperature and the reaction was left for the required time. The products after reaction were analyzed by GC (Shimadzu GC-2–14C, FID) with a DM-WAX column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm) and GC–MS (Thermal Trace GC Ultra with a Polaris Q ion trap mass spectrometer equipped with a TR-5MS capillary column). The calculation of FUR conversion, product selectivity, and productivity was based on the following equations. The carbon balance was well than 95 %. (1) FUR conversion ( % ) = 100 − m o l e s o f s u b s t r a t e r e s i d u a l m o l e s o f s u b s t r a t e i n i t i a l l y × 100 (2) Selectivity ( % ) = m o l e s o f s p e c i f i c p r o d u c t s u m o f m o l e s o f d e t e c t e d o r g a n i c c o m p o u n d s × 100 (3) Productivity ( gFOL · gCo − 1 · h − 1 ) = m a s s o f F O L p r o d u c e d m a s s o f c o b a l t u s e d × h o u r s o f r e a c t i o n Result and discussion Synthesis of Co-MOF by coordinating cobalt ions with H2-BDC ligands Upon mixing cobalt ions with a mixed solvent, a transparent purple solution was obtained, which can remain unchanged even after undergoing hydrothermal treatment. As the ligands H2-BDC were mixed with the cobalt ions, pink precipitation was formed (seeing Figure S1 in SI), indicating strong coordination between the H2-BDC and cobalt ions that resulted in the production of Co-MOF. SEM images showcasing the as-synthesized Co-MOF is presented in Fig. 1 , where we can see a nest-like aggregation of 5–6 μm. This aggregated morphology can be interpreted as an assembly of short nanosheets with a size range of 500–800 nm. Other researchers have also reported the usage of H2-BDC as ligands to obtain nanosheet-like morphology[37,38]. The crystallinity of the resulting Co-MOF was assessed and characterized in Fig. 2a . The peaks in the XRD pattern are in agreement with those Co-MOF reported in the literature[39,40]. Specifically, the peaks at 8.9 and 18.1 o of 2θ correspond to the lamellar matrix of Co-MOF, which is often recognized as one of the reasons for the formation of sheet-like morphology. The nitrogen sorption plot, as depicted in Fig. 2b , indicates that the adsorption behavior of Co-MOF follows an III-type model based on Bunauer's classification. Notably, a bimodal porosity spanning the range of 5–20 nm and 30–200 nm is observed. This dual porosity can be attributed to the intertexture of nanosheets or the aggregation of particles. In the Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of Fig. 2c, the Co-MOF held most of the peaks attributed to the H2-BDC ligands. Specifically, the asymmetric stretching of carboxyl groups is observed at 1630–1680 cm−1, symmetric stretching of C = O groups occurs at 1402 cm−1, CH stretching in the benzene ring is identified at 1140, 1100 cm−1, etc.[40–42]. Notably, a prominent blue shift from 1680 to 1630 − 1 upon the Co-MOF coordination suggests the formation of coordination bonds between the cobalt ions and H2-BDC ligands[43]. Fig. 2d shows the view of the Co-MOF along the b-axis, in which the H2-BDC ligands serve as a bridge to link the CoO6 octahedral units, constructing a layered three-dimensional structure[40]. Pyrolysis of Co-MOF to in situ generate carbon-coated cobalt catalysts Co@C A well-designed pyrolysis process could strongly affect the cobalt phase and carbon porosity, which is the key to access a carbon-supported cobalt catalyst; thus, we prepared a series of Co@C-T-n with various pyrolysis temperatures, where the T-n refers to the pyrolysis temperature. We initially examined the TG-DTG-DSC curves to explore the thermal properties of Co-MOF during pyrolysis. The TG curve (Fig. 3a ) exhibits three distinct regions corresponding to different pyrolysis kinetic. In the first region (50∼370 °C), an initial weight loss of ca. 5 % occurs due to the elimination of adsorbed water. This is followed by a subsequent weight loss of ca. 55 % in the range of 370∼550 °C, attributed to the pyrolysis of organic ligands. Beyond 550 °C, the system enters a thermally stable region [44]. Notably, the second region shows three prominent DTG peaks, indicating rapid pyrolysis kinetics. Consistent with this observation, three small DSC peaks are observed, indicating exothermic processes during this stage [40,45]. Comparing the TG curve of pure H2-BDC, seeing the dotted gray line and Fig. 3, we found that the coordination between the cobalt and H2-BDC renders the onset of pyrolysis temperature shifting toward high temperature (∼50 °C), suggesting the strong interaction between the ligands and cobalt ions. Correspondingly, the FTIR spectra in Fig. 3b demonstrate the change in the stretching of carbonyl group, as indicated by the characteristic bands at 1580 and 1500 cm−1, upon the pyrolysis. These distinct peaks persist in Co@C-T350, where the crystal structure of the Co-MOF crystal remains intact. Then they start to weaken in Co@C-T400, indicating the reduction of cobalt ions into CoOx. Finally, these peaks disappear in Co@C-T450, implying the dominance of CoOx in the cobalt phase. Fig. 4a shows the XRD pattern, revealing the crystallite phase for the Co@C-T-n. In Fig. 4b, the percentage of cobalt phase (CoO and metallic Co) and crystallite size are plotted against the pyrolysis temperature. Likewise, the crystallite phase undergoes changes corresponding to the carbonization temperature. The Co@C-T350 maintains its Co-MOF crystalline structure. The CoO phase (characterized by 36°, 42°, 62° and 73° of 2θ) [46,47] emerges on the Co@C-T400 alongside a reduction in the Co-MOF phase, and dominates the crystal phase on the Co@C-T450. Further elevate the temperature, the metallic cobalt (44°, 52° and 76° of 2θ) almost wholly substitutes the CoO phase on the Co@C-T500 [28,29,48,49]. The crystallite size of cobalt nanoparticles maintains a relatively narrow size range of 15–20 nm as the pyrolysis temperature increases. This indicates their excellent resistance to metal-sintering. The small particle size facilitates the accessibility of cobalt species, thus suggesting high catalytic activity. Besides the crystal phase of cobalt, the pyrolysis temperature can tune the carbon porosity. These Co@C-T-n catalysts exhibit similar profiles as those of Co-MOF, except for an emerging sorption step near the p/p0 =0, which increases with the pyrolysis temperature elevation (Fig. 5a ). As a result, besides the original bimodal porosity, a new micropore of 1–2 nm arises and increases to some extent upon the pyrolysis temperature, as shown in Fig. 5b. Combining the TG results (Fig. 3a), these newly emerged micropores should be ascribed to the removal of organic constituents within the sheet-like Co-MOF, which occurs in the corresponding temperature range of 400–550 °C. Fig. 5c plots the capacity evolution for the surface area and micropores as a function of pyrolysis temperature. High pyrolysis temperature results in increased surface area and microporosity, reaching the maximum values at around 550–575 °C. To offer more detailed information about the surface composition of catalysts, we conducted the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization, as presented in Fig. 6 . The Co 2p3/2 spectra are analyzed and fitted with three individual peaks, attributable to the satellite shake-up peak (∼787 eV), Co2+ (∼782.5 eV), Co3+ (∼780.5 eV) and Co0 (∼779.3 eV) species, respectively[28,29,33,50,51]. With the increase in temperature, the intensity of the satellite peak weakens, and the population of the oxidized cobalt species (Co2+ and Co3+) gradually decreases—an observation akin to that of copper catalysts [52]. Consistent with this trend, the binding energies shift towards lower values and the amount of metallic cobalt species increases. Such an energy shift can be ascribed to the presence of metallic cobalt, and, potentially, to the charge transfer from the carbon to the cobalt[53,54]. However, it should be noted that even when subjected to high pyrolysis temperatures (500–600 °C), the Co@C sample still retains a certain proportion of oxidized cobalt species due to the inevitable passivation of surface cobalt during the sample preparation process. The increased number of surface metallic cobalt in Co@C-T500 and Co@C-T550, seeing Table S2 in SI, suggests that high pyrolysis temperatures could somewhat resist surface oxidation, which could also be seen as the result of strong interaction between the carbon and cobalt, as is indicated by the prominent charge transfer binding energy shift (seeing the dotted line in Fig. 6a). In the C 1 s spectra, the 284.8, 286 and 289 eV peaks are assigned to the C=C/C-C, C-O and O-C=O species[55,56]. The appearance of the O-C=O peak originates from residual carbon in organic ligands, which diminishes at higher pyrolysis temperatures. The morphology evolution upon the pyrolysis temperature is observed by the SEM images in Fig. 7 . The sheet-like morphology can be maintained intact as the Co-MOF crystallite is preserved. Upon pyrolysis, a portion of the Co-MOF underwent reduction of cobalt ions, leading to the formation of either CoO or metallic cobalt species. As a result, the nano-sheets exhibited shrinkage and folding, transforming into mono-dispersed nanoparticles within a size range of 50–100 nm, as shown in Co@C-T450. Interestingly, mono-dispersed microspheres of 1 μm are produced for the Co@C-T550, which can be seen as a spontaneous aggregation of these preformed cobalt nanoparticles (average size of 62 nm, Figure S3 in SI) undergoing pyrolysis. This unique nanoparticle-aggregate-microsphere may be associated with the sheet-like morphology of Co-MOF, and afford both highly-dispersed cobalt nanoparticles and mass-transfer channels, which may differentiate our Co@C from others[26,32,57,58]. Fig. 8 illustrates the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of the Co@C-T550 sample. In Fig. 8b, the presence of a carbon coating with an approximate thickness of 5 nm is evident. The underlying carbon shell reveals lattice fringes measuring 0.20 nm and 0.24 nm, corresponding to the metal cobalt (111) and CoOx (220) inter-planes, respectively, as supported by previous studies[26,28,29,59]. The element mapping in Fig. 8c -f provides a visual representation of the distribution of each element, thereby confirming the core-shell structure by comparing the respective coverage regions. The presence of oxygen may originate from the passivation during sample preparation, according to our XPS analysis above. Based on the aforementioned findings and discussions, we depict the fabrication route for the Co@C, as shown in Scheme 1 above. The selected H2-BDC ligands and cobalt ions were dissolved simultaneously with a mixed solution (DMF+water+ethanol) in an autoclave, in which they coordinate simultaneously and form nanosheets via solvothermal synthesis. Underwent pyrolysis, these nanosheets are carbonized into carbon-coated cobalt nanoparticles, which are assembled into microspheres occasionally. Selective hydrogenation of FUR toward FOL Hydrogenative upgrading of furfural over the cobalt catalyst follows the reaction path shown in Scheme 2 , whereby the furfuryl alcohol (FOL) serves as a crucial intermediate leading to the production of 2-methyl furan (2-MF) or tetrahydro-furfuryl alcohol (THFOL), depending on specific catalysts and reaction parameters employed. In general, low temperature favors a high yield of FOL, while high temperature promotes the production of THFOL and 2-MF. Achieving a high FOL yield necessitates the utilization of a catalyst that exhibits exceptional activity under mild temperature conditions. The cobalt could activate the hydrogenation dissociation even at room temperature [60], which may allow a high FOL yield at a mild reaction. In a previous study[61], we reported a CoOx#TiO2 catalyst for furfural hydrogenation, which presented a high FOL productivity (31 gFOL·gCo −1·h − 1) at 140 °C, but rapidly decreased as the temperature declined. Herein, given a very mild reaction condition of 80 °C and 1 MPa of pH2, we evaluated the catalyst performance for our newly advanced Co@C catalyst. The blank tests ran without any catalyst or with pristine carbon suggest negligible FUR conversion (Entry 1–2, Table S3 in SI), while the pristine Co-MOF demonstrates trivial activity (Entry 3 in Table S3). As the metallic cobalt is introduced, the FUR conversion is observable on those tested catalysts. Both Co NPs and CoOx#TiO2 show low activity (<5 %), whereas the Co@C-T-n series display a FUR conversion following a volcano-type trend. Specifically, the Co@C-T-n carbonized at a temperature ≤ 450 oC has a very low FUR conversion (<10 %). When the metallic cobalt dictates the cobalt phase, the conversion rises gradually and reaches the highest value (63 %) for the Co@C-T550. These results suggest that the metallic cobalt sites, rather than the pristine Co-MOF or CoO, are the active centers for hydrogenation. Hence, we estimated the surface metallic cobalt sites based on the particle size and XPS-derived surface composition to justify the activity evolution trend, seeing Fig. 9b and Table S2 in SI. The FUR conversion correlates well with the surface metallic cobalt sites, suggesting the improved surface active sites responsible for the enhanced hydrogenation activity. Optimizing the pyrolysis conditions is crucial for achieving the desired catalytic performance. Previous studies by other scientists have reported that the optimized pyrolysis temperature ranged from 500 to 700 °C [29,30,62], which strongly relied on the synthesized strategies and kinds of reaction. In our case, considering the structural characterization results and reaction outcomes, the activity evolution with the pyrolysis temperature can be elucidated as follows: i) insufficient reduction degree is responsible for the low activity of Co@C pyrolyzed at low temperature (< 550 °C), and ii) particle growth and surface shrink lead to the activity decline on Co@C at high temperature, for example, Co@C-T600. Furthermore, under the given reaction conditions, it is noteworthy that furfuryl alcohol is the sole product obtained over the Co@C catalysts, in line with the finding that low temperature favors the production of FOL. To validate the reaction pathway mentioned in Scheme 2 and acquire a completed conversion of FUR on the optimized Co@C, we plotted the FUR conversion and product selectivity as a function of reaction time, seeing Fig. 10a . The Co@C-T550 converts the FUR linearly in the initial 60 min with the FOL being the exclusive product. Beyond 60 % conversion of the FUR, the FOL selectivity starts to decline, accompanied by a negligible amount (∼1 %) of the side products, such as tetrahydro furfuryl alcohol (THFOL) and 2-methyl furan (2-MF). The high FOL selectivity (>95 %) is sustained until the reaction proceeds 180 min, where the FUR is almost completely converted. Notably, when the FOL is used as the substrate, only a limited conversion (<5 %) is observed. These results indicate that, under the given conditions, the Co@C-T550 has a high activity of FUR hydrogenation to FOL, but low activity for further converting the FOL. Therefore, by selecting an appropriate reaction time, it is possible to achieve an excellent yield of FOL from FUR hydrogenation using the Co@C catalyst. It is noteworthy that conducting reactions at such low temperatures (∼80 °C) over the carbon-supported cobalt catalysts has been reported in some studies [54,62]. However, reports demonstrating high furfuryl alcohol (FOL) productivity under these conditions are relatively scarce. We compiled data on several representative carbon-supported cobalt catalysts in Fig. 10b and Table S1. Our Co@C-T550 exhibits an outstanding FOL productivity of 4.8 gFOL·gCo −1·h − 1 at 80 °C, surpassing the majority of catalysts reported by other research groups. This intriguing catalytic performance can primarily attributed to the abundant surface metallic cobalt sites, as confirmed by the XPS, XRD and HRTEM analysis. These catalytic sites benefit from the highly dispersed cobalt nanoparticles, sound resist-oxidation properties, aggregated-microsphere morphology and carbon-coated construction. Subsequently, we investigate and evaluate the performance of Co@C-T550 across a range of reaction temperatures and hydrogen pressure. The hydrogenation activity is strongly influenced by both the hydrogen pressure and temperature, as depicted in Fig. 11a . Analysis of the data obtained at various reaction temperatures enabled us to construct the Arrhenius curve for the Co@C-T550 catalyst (inset Fig. 11a), revealing an apparent activation energy (Ea) of approximately 40.7 kJ/mol. This value is comparable with the ones of several cobalt catalysts reported for mild furfural hydrogenation (50∼90 °C), as summarized in Table S4 in SI. Also, the decreased Ea suggests the lowered energy barrier for the Co@C-T550, which aligns well with its impressive activity compared to that of the Co NPs and CoOx#TiO2. In terms of product selectivity, the FOL is the dominant product within the given temperature range (80∼130 °C), particularly at low temperatures. When the reaction temperature rises, side products such as THFOL and 2-MF produced from the furan-ring hydrogenation and dehydroxylation become more prevalent, as shown in Fig. 11b. These results demonstrate the pivotal role of high activity under mild conditions in achieving a high yield of FOL. Reusability evaluation Besides the low-temperature activity, stability is another important consideration in practical usage for the supported catalysts. One widely recognized advantage of carbon-coating is its remarkable resistance to sintering and leaching during recycling operations. As expected, the Co@C-T550 demonstrates robust stability with limited activity and selectivity decline (<1 %) after 10 times consecutive runs (Fig. 12a ). To assess if the catalyst structure and composition are altered, we characterized the spent Co@C-T550 after 10 times runs, as presented in Fig. 12b -d. Compared with the fresh one, the spent Co@C-T550 shows a limited change in the cobalt crystalline phase, surface composition and surface area, as justified by the XRD, XPS and nitrogen sorption, etc. Encouragingly, ICP analysis confirms that the cobalt content remains nearly unchanged after repeated runs (Table S5 in SI). In a word, these findings validate the merit of the carbon-coating structure in effectively mitigating metal sintering and leaching phenomena. Conclusion In summary, based on the synthesis of sheet-like Co-MOF utilizing H2-BDC as organic ligands, we have successfully synthesized a novel and highly efficient catalyst comprising carbon-coated cobalt nanoparticles catalyst, Co@C, for the mild furfural hydrogenation. Beneficial to the carbon-coating and monodispersed particle size distribution, the optimized Co@C-T550 (pyrolysis temperature of 550 °C) had highly dispersed particle size and sound ability to resist sintering and reoxidation, affording a high number of active metallic cobalt sites. Consequently, this catalyst exhibits an outstanding productivity of FOL (4.8 gFOL·gCo −1·h−1) during mild furfural hydrogenation (80 °C and 1 MPa), surpassing the performance of most recently reported cobalt-based catalysts. Furthermore, the Co@C-T550 catalyst demonstrates reliable stability, exhibiting only marginal activity decay even after being subjected to ten cycles of recycling. This study expands the potential application of carbon-coated cobalt catalysts in the realm of low-temperature hydrogenation for biomass valorization. coredata.dc:description: The hydrogenative upgrading of furfural into valuable chemical intermediates has currently caught intensive research interest, with robust and efficient catalysts that can operate under mild reaction conditions remaining challenging. In this study, we presented a high-performance carbon-coated cobalt catalyst (Co@C) through pyrolysis of sheet-like Co-MOF. The optimized Co@C-T550 exhibited an intriguing furfural conversion rate under a very mild reaction condition of 80 °C and 1 MPa. The catalyst's enhanced activity at low-temperature effectively suppressed side reactions, resulting in an excellent furfuryl alcohol productivity of 4.8 gFOL·gCo −1·h−1, surpassing most cobalt-based catalysts reported in recent literature. Furthermore, the high performance of Co@C-T550 can be sustained with slight decay even after undergoing 10 recycling runs, underscoring the reliable stability of the catalyst. Structure characterizations have revealed that this novel Co@C-T550 had highly dispersed cobalt nanoparticles with a microporous carbon coating, affording a high number of metallic cobalt sites with an excellent ability to resist cobalt sintering/leaching and re-oxidation. The insights gained from this study provide a solid foundation for the rational design of advanced carbon-coated cobalt catalysts for low-temperature hydrogenative biomass upgrading.
coredata.dc:title: A highly accessible and robust carbon-coated cobalt nanoparticle catalyst for furfural hydrogenative valorization at mild reaction
